central_thesis: The author's sole aim is to demonstrate the logical possibility of precognition leading to intervention by presenting alternative models of time (specifically, configurations of the 'block model' of space-time) that circumvent the 'Intervention Paradox', thereby showing it is not an inherent barrier to such precognition.

structure_content.summary: The article's aim is to show that the Intervention Paradox does not inherently prevent precognition where the foreseen event can be avoided or altered. It focuses on constructing theoretical models of the universe that allow for this type of precognition, without arguing for its existence or specific mechanisms.

For the purpose of this article, precognition is defined as a direct sensing of future events or possible futures that 'exist' by some unknown psi mechanism, differentiating it from mere forecasting based on known data. This is the type of precognition for which the Intervention Paradox poses a problem.

This section introduces the 'block universe' model (also known as 'block space-time' or 'B-series') as the dominant mainstream view of time in philosophy and physics. In this 4-dimensional model, space and time are joined into a static entity, where all moments (past, present, future) have equal status of existence. This model supports the idea that the future already exists.

structure_content.chapter_title: Time and Motion and the 'Now' Moment
structure_content.summary: Addresses the perceived lack of a 'now' moment or 'motion through time' in the static block universe model. It argues that subjective experiences of a 'present moment' and 'motion' can be incorporated into the block model through an observer's memory and consciousness, without necessitating an infinite regression of time dimensions or denying determinism/free will, making it a useful conceptual tool.

Defines the Intervention Paradox (as per Thalbourne) where a precognitive impression of event E leads to action preventing E, questioning the original cause of the impression. The article illustrates this conflict and proposes a scenario (Figure 5) where the precognitive impression P is linked to the *avoided* outcome (E2) rather than the original event E, thus removing the logical contradiction and making the scenario self-consistent.

Presents a solution to the Intervention Paradox by proposing a block universe with 'many futures' or 'parallel universes'. In this model, a bifurcation occurs, allowing both the future where event E happens (causing precognition P) and an alternative future where action is taken to avoid E (resulting in E2) to coexist. This concept is likened to the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics, where all 'possible' futures actually exist.

Introduces a second solution involving a 'higher' time dimension (Time 2) orthogonal to our conventional time (Time 1). This 2-time block universe allows for different temporal histories to exist along the Time 2 axis. Thus, a future where E occurs and a 'later' future (in Time 2) where precognition leads to E being avoided can both 'exist' simultaneously within the 5-dimensional structure. The article suggests this model may be conceptually equivalent to the 'many futures' model.

The article concludes that the block universe model confirms the existence of the future. The Intervention Paradox can be circumvented if one abandons the assumptions of 'only one future' or 'only one time dimension'. The proposed models demonstrate that precognition leading to intervention is logically consistent within plausible cosmological frameworks.

key_concepts.definition: If a person has a precognitive impression of an event E, and as a result of this information takes action such that E subsequently fails to occur, then the Intervention Paradox is the question of what it was that caused the precognitive impression in the first place, since the putative cause, viz. the future event E, never came into being. (Thalbourne, 2003, p. 57)
Precognition which involves the direct sensing by some unknown mechanism of future events or possible futures which in some sense exist.

A philosophical and physical model where all points in time (past, present, and future) and space exist simultaneously and equally, forming a static 4-dimensional (or higher) structure, often conceptualized as a 'block' or 'sculpture' where time is an extended dimension like space.

A theoretical model, analogous to the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics, where at points of decision or quantum interaction, the universe (and observers) splits into multiple co-existing branches, each representing a different possible outcome, all of which actually exist, thus providing distinct paths for precognitive information and subsequent intervention.

A theoretical model of a 5-dimensional block universe where an additional 'higher' time dimension (Time 2) exists at right angles to the conventional time dimension (Time 1). This allows for multiple temporal histories to co-exist along the higher time axis, permitting a 'changing future' relative to Time 1 within a larger static structure.

A term associated with Relativity theory that describes the motion of an entity or observer through space and time, represented as a continuous path or 'strand of spaghetti' within the static block universe.

practical_system.description: This article does not present a practical system or manual for occult or magical practice. Instead, it offers theoretical philosophical and physics-based models of space-time designed to logically reconcile the concept of precognition with the ability to intervene and change future events, thereby resolving the 'Intervention Paradox'. Its 'system' is purely conceptual, providing frameworks (such as the block universe with multiple futures or with an additional time dimension) within which precognitive intervention could be consistent.

relevant_quotes.text: The author aims to show that there are possible models of time for which the Intervention Paradox is not a barrier to the possible existence of a type of precognition in which the event precognised is avoided or changed.

If a person has a precognitive impression of an event E, and as a result of this information takes action such that E subsequently fails to occur, then the Intervention Paradox is the question of what it was that caused the precognitive impression in the first place, since the putative cause, viz. the future event E, never came into being.

What we end up with is what is called in philosophy "block space-time" (also called the 'B-series') ... I shall call it the "block universe" because it includes not only space and time, but everything else as well, all incorporated into a 4-D sculpture of incredible complexity.
The 'block universe' is a gigantic and incredibly complex 'static' piece of sculpture.

The block model can accommodate as many futures as we want—it just makes the structure more complex, that's all. All futures co-exist from our god's eye viewpoint outside the block universe—they are not 'possible' futures, they are all there.

A 2-time block universe can resolve another issue about 'changing the future'. Intuitively it may be felt that precognition is a problem because it is changing a future which otherwise would have gone in a different direction. ... But in the 2-time universe changing the future is no problem.

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is highly relevant to theoretical parapsychology and the philosophy of time, addressing a significant conceptual hurdle for the logical consistency of precognition that involves free will and intervention. By grounding its models in interpretations of modern physics, it shifts the discussion of such phenomena from mere anecdote to theoretical possibility, offering a framework where precognitive intervention is not inherently paradoxical.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is academic researchers and scholars in parapsychology, philosophy of time, theoretical physics, and consciousness studies. The article's technical language and reliance on abstract models of space-time assume a high level of familiarity with these specialized fields, making it less suitable for a general audience or practitioners seeking practical guidance.
